In python 3.7 you might be able to hack something using https://docs.python.org/3/library/gc.html#gc.freeze

    allocate_a_lot()
    gc.freeze() # move all objects to a permanent generation. none will be collected

I'm trying to build a platformer but I can't figure out how to stop my character from going into the sides of the platform. I was able to figure out how to stop the character from going through the bottom and the top but the sides stump me. Here's the code related to the collisions.

```py
if player.vel.y > 0:
    hits = pygame.sprite.spritecollide(player, platforms, False)
    if hits:
        player.pos.y = hits[0].rect.top + 0.5
        player.vel.y = 0
if player.vel.y < 0:
    hits = pygame.sprite.spritecollide(player, platforms, False)
    if hits:
        player.vel.y = 0
```
        
                

Here's the rest of it if you need it. Any help will be appreciated.

```py
import pygame
import random

vec = pygame.math.Vector2
width = 800
height = 350
fps = 30

platform_moving_list = [(width/2, height/2, 100, 30),
                     (width - 100, height* 3/4, 100, 30)]

player_acc = 0.5
player_friction = -0.06
gravity = 0.6
# define colors
white = (255, 255, 255)
black = (0, 0, 0)
red = (255, 0, 0)
green = (0, 255, 0)
blue = (0, 0, 255)

player_width = 50

# initialize pygame and create window
pygame.init()
pygame.mixer.init()
screen = pygame.display.set_mode((width, height))
pygame.display.set_caption("Game")
clock = pygame.time.Clock()

class Player(pygame.sprite.Sprite):
    def __init__(self):
        pygame.sprite.Sprite.__init__(self)
        self.image = pygame.Surface((player_width, 40))
        self.image.fill(red)
        self.rect = self.image.get_rect()
        self.rect.center = (width/2,0)
        self.pos = vec(width/2, 0)
        self.vel = vec(0, 0)
        self.acc = vec(0,0)

    def update(self):
        self.acc = vec(0,gravity)
        keys = pygame.key.get_pressed()
        if keys[pygame.K_LEFT]:
            self.acc.x = -player_acc
        if keys[pygame.K_RIGHT]:
            self.acc.x = player_acc
        self.acc.x += self.vel.x * player_friction    
        self.vel += self.acc
        self.pos += self.vel + 0.5*self.acc

        self.rect.center = self.pos
        if self.rect.right > width:
            self.acc.x = 0
            self.vel.x = 0
            self.rect.right = width
        if self.rect.left < 0:
            self.acc.x = 0
            self.vel.x = 0
            self.rect.left = 0

        self.rect.midbottom = self.pos
    def jump(self):
        self.rect.x += 1
        hits = pygame.sprite.spritecollide(self, platforms, False)
        self.rect.x -= 1
        if hits:
            self.vel.y = -15

class Platform(pygame.sprite.Sprite):
    def __init__(self, x, y, w, h):
        pygame.sprite.Sprite.__init__(self)
        self.image = pygame.Surface((w,h))
        self.image.fill(green)
        self.rect = self.image.get_rect()
        self.rect.x = x
        self.rect.y = y

all_sprites = pygame.sprite.Group()
platforms = pygame.sprite.Group()

player = Player()
all_sprites.add(player)
for plat in platform_moving_list:
    p = Platform(*plat)
    all_sprites.add(p)
    platforms.add(p)
ground = Platform(0, height - 30, width, 30)
all_sprites.add(ground)
platforms.add(ground)
# Game loop
running = True
while running:
    # keep loop running at the right speed
    clock.tick(fps)
    # Process input (events)
    for event in pygame.event.get():
        # check for closing window
        if event.type == pygame.QUIT:
            running = False
        if event.type == pygame.KEYDOWN:
            if event.key == pygame.K_UP:
                player.jump()

    # Update
    all_sprites.update()

    if player.vel.y > 0:
        hits = pygame.sprite.spritecollide(player, platforms, False)
        if hits:
            player.pos.y = hits[0].rect.top + 0.5
            player.vel.y = 0
    if player.vel.y < 0:
        hits = pygame.sprite.spritecollide(player, platforms, False)
        if hits:
            player.vel.y = 0

    # Draw / render
    screen.fill(black)
    all_sprites.draw(screen)
    # *after* drawing everything, flip the display
    pygame.display.flip()

pygame.quit()
```

answers.body_markdown:
You can use `COUNT(DISTINCT ..)` on a custom string made out of `org_id`, `country` and `text`. This would ensure that only unique combinations of them are counted (thus emulating GROUP BY and then COUNT). 

I have used an arbitrary delimiter `&&`. If your `text` or `country` column can contain this delimiter, then you can use some other uncommon character combination as delimiter: 

```sql
select 
  COUNT(DISTINCT CONCAT(org_id, '&&', country, '&&', text)), 
  sum(impressions) as imp, 
  sum(taps) as taps
from report 
where org_id = 1 and report_date between '2019-01-01' and '2019-10-10'
```

For good performance, define the following composite index on `report` table: `(org_id, report_date)`

answers.body_markdown:
Dummy arguments, also called function parameters in other programming languages, must be declared inside the function or subroutine.

Also, the argument list (the argument names in the parentheses after the subroutine name) should not contain any additional parentheses.

    module test
      implicit none
    
    contains
    
      subroutine sumsize(x,su,si)    
        real,  intent(in) :: x(:)
        real, intent(out) :: su, si
    
        su=sum(x(:))
        si=size(x(:))
      end subroutine
    end module

Also, you typically do not want the dummy argument to be `allocatable`. That is normally used when the array is allocated or deallocated inside the subroutine or if you want to allow working with an unallocated array.

    program test
      implicit none
    
      real, allocatable :: main_x(:)
      real :: main_su, main_si
    
      allocate(main_x(3))
      main_x(:) = (/1,2,3/)
    
      call  sumsize(main_x, main_su, main_si)
    end program

I renamed the variables with the `main_`prefix. It is not needed, it is just to make clear that they are distinct from the names inside the subroutine.

answers.body_markdown:
You cannot make a 64-bit integer type simply by making a structure or a union that contains 64 bits, regardless of what the internal members of that structure or union are. C has no provisions for converting integers to such a type or for doing any arithmetic on them.

To implement 64-bit integers without direct support from the compiler, you must write your own routines to do whichever operations you need, potentially including:

* Given two 32-bit integers that represent a 64-bit number in “base 2<sup>32</sup>”, convert them to your 64-bit type.
* Convert from your 64-bit type to two 32-bit integers.

answers.title: How to select strings not containing a word using regular expression?

answers.body_markdown:
Just use negative lookahead:

    (?!.*data)

Meaning "assert that what follows is not: zero or more of any characters followed by `data`".

I'd suggest also turning on single line mode by `(?s)` - dot will match also newline character `(?s)(?!.*data)`

If pattern is matched, you can delete the string, as it doesn't contain `data`.
answers.title: How to select strings not containing a word using regular expression?

answers.body_markdown:
You already have the optimal solution with sub-selects.

Pseudo code:

    SELECT *
      FROM OriginalData
      WHERE (POB, ValidFrom)
         IN (SELECT POB, MIN(ValidFrom)
              FROM OriginalData
              GROUP BY POB)
        OR (POB, ValidTo)
         IN (SELECT POB, MAX(ValidTo)
               FROM OriginalData
               GROUP BY POB);

GROUP BY won't work as it "mixes up" the minimums in different columns.

A nice touch might be extracting the sub-selects into views of their own, eg. EarliestContractPerPob and LatestContractPerPob.

answers.body_markdown:
The simplest way to loop over an integer vector is probably a `for loop`:

    for (x in 1:28) {
     scrape_function(x, api_key)
    }

You could translate this in a base R `lapply`:

    lapply(1:28, function(x) {scrape_function(x, api_key)})

Or in a `purrr::map` call which allows the shorter lambda (~) function notation:

    purrr::map(1:28, ~ scrape_function(.x, api_key))

Note that `lapply` and `map` will both produce the desired side-effect (of writing the JSON files) and a list as output. If you are only interested in the side-effects you might as well use `walk`.

    purrr::walk(1:28, ~ scrape_function(.x, api_key))

`walk` not only produces side-effects, it can also return the original object which was passed into it when piping `%>%` the output into another function or when set visible using `(`. In our case this would be the integer vector `1:28`.

    (purrr::walk(1:28, ~ scrape_function(.x, api_key)))

The issue was based on not setting the Region inside of the Env variable you can generate signed URL's with the following:

```haskell
getPresignedURL :: Region
                -> BucketName
                -> ObjectKey
                -> IO ByteString
getPresignedURL r b k = do
    lgr <- newLogger Trace stdout
    env <- newEnv $ FromKeys (AccessKey $ encodeUtf8 $ aKeyE) (SecretKey $ encodeUtf8 $ sKeyE)
    let nEnv = env & envRegion .~ r
    ts  <- getCurrentTime 
    runResourceT . runAWST nEnv $ presignURL ts 900 (putObject b k "Content-Type=image/jpeg")
```

Im not very familiar with lenses so i am sure there is a more succinct way to do the following:

```haskell
    env <- newEnv $ FromKeys (AccessKey $ encodeUtf8 $ aKeyE) (SecretKey $ encodeUtf8 $ sKeyE)
    let nEnv = env & envRegion .~ r
```

You can avoid the ```while``` loop part which is taking more time in your code. You can try the following code which does not have ```while``` condition in for loop. Execution time for both the implementaions is given below for comparison.
```python3
import itertools
import random
import time
####### this part is for generating list of random numbers has length 10000 ####### 
def random_gen(low, high):
    while True:
        yield random.randrange(low, high)

gen = random_gen(1, 100)
input = list(itertools.islice(gen, 10000))
##############################################################################
num = 3
count = 0

start = time.time() # start time for calculating time 

for i in range(1,len(input)):
    if input[i-1] < input[i]:
        continue
    elif input[i-1] == input[i]:
        input[i] = input[i]+num
        count+=1
    elif input[i-1] > input[i]:
        diff = input[i-1] - input[i]
        quotiont = (diff//num)+1
        input[i] += quotiont*num
        count+=quotiont

end = time.time() # end time after processing list

print(count)
print(input)
print(end-start)
```
Output: Execution time using this implementation on my machine is:
```
0.01267862319946289
```
Output Execution time using your code is:
```
13.800339698791504
```

I'm assuming your table is also the form's recordset here. If it is not you will need something to determine which record in the table you want to edit.

```
Private Sub Delivered_AfterUpdate()
    If Me.Delivered = True Then  
        With Me.Recordset
             .Edit
             ![ImplementationDate] = Now()
             .Update
        End With
    End If
End Sub
```
You can leave ```Me.Delivered = -1``` if you want but I find True/False to be easier to read.

I also recommend not naming something Date, I'm not sure if it actually matters as a column name, but it is both a builtin function and data type. So I changed it.

You should also indent your code, it will be a nightmare as you get more lines.

answers.body_markdown:
Your command looks for `filesystem` at the beginning of the line. There are two problems with that:

1. The string you're looking for begins with `/filesystem`, not `filesystem`; and
2. it's not at the beginning of the line, it's the last field in the line.

You can use `awk` and get the last field with `$NF`.

```
df -h | awk '$NF ~ /^\/filesystem/'
```

answers.body_markdown:
The error message in https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39083375/expected-closure-found-a-different-closure happens because `Vec<T>` can only hold closures of one concrete type `T`. In your case, it looks easier to add a second type parameter `U`, so that you can hold two different closures of different types:

```
struct HasWithCall<T, U>
where
    T: SafeFnMut,
    U: SafeFnMut,
{
    pub first_fn: Option<Box<WithCall<T>>>,
    pub second_fn: Option<Box<WithCall<U>>>,
}
```

([full example](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=4bd86e323a03aedcd85228569956a4f7))

As a side note, the extra `Box` seems unnecessary to me; it's probably sufficient to use `Option<WithCall<T>>` since there is a `Box` inside `WithCall`.

I'm trying to create an input/search field in an excel sheet that when someone enters data in the field, it starts autopopulating from X Range, when they find the data they want they hit enter and it pulls from Y Range.

Closest I've found is `XLOOKUP`, but I can't get it to work on a field when someone types into that field. I want this to work through column A of the entire sheet, so when the user goes to a new line it does the same as the line above.

So, input data into A4, while typing it search C:C and auto fills in as I type. Once I find what I like I hit enter and it pulls the cell next to the C cell I found the data on, resulting cell data, so D:D column.

[![enter image description here][1]][1]

I've tried inputing this into a dropdown validate field, but no go, just errors out:

```
=XLOOKUP(INDIRECT("a9"), C:C, D:D)
```

answers.body_markdown:
Adsense doesn't deny applications due to them being single-page. It should give you a reason behind your denial, likely not enough content or detail. 

You should look at your app and think "could I fit ads here?" if yes, review your app and judge the amount of content you have. If no, reconsider your design to better fit placing ads in your app.
